metadata.synopsis: Laezel discusses and unlocks the orpheus chapters.
metadata.how_to_trigger: Triggers if you ask Laezel about the Orpheus Chapters in the DefaultQuestionBank

29.speaker: Lae'zel
29.text: *The disc appears in your mind's eye. Lae'zel sees it too, and considers the vision.*
29.context: NodeContext: Arrogance-- 'why are you bothering me?'

41.speaker: Player
41.text: *The disc appears in your mind's eye. Lae'zel sees it too, and considers the vision.*
41.context: NodeContext: TEAR-soo. (A kind of writing.) Curious.

89.speaker: Narrator
89.text: *The disc appears in your mind's eye. Lae'zel sees it too, and considers the vision.*

66.speaker: Lae'zel
66.text: The texts are enciphered, but there's a Commonspeech translation beneath, carved in a different hand.

137.speaker: Lae'zel
137.text: It's a story about - about Orpheus.

162.speaker: Narrator
162.text: *Your mind connects with Lae'zel's, and together you envision the githyanki disc.*

38.speaker: Lae'zel
38.text: Another part of the Orpheus tale. This one has been translated to Common.

179.speaker: Player
179.text: I'd like to hear you tell the story.

74.speaker: Player
74.text: No need to read it aloud.

116.speaker: Lae'zel
116.text: Another part of the Orpheus tale. It reads as follows:

47.speaker: Player
47.text: *The disc appears in your mind's eye. Lae'zel sees it too, and considers the vision.*
47.context: NodeContext: TEAR-soo. (A kind of writing.) Curious.

43.speaker: Player
43.text: *The disc appears in your mind's eye. Lae'zel sees it too, and considers the vision.*
43.context: NodeContext: TEAR-soo. (A kind of writing.) Curious.

99.speaker: Narrator
99.text: *The disc appears in your mind's eye. Lae'zel sees it too, and considers the vision.*
99.context: NodeContext: TEAR-soo. (A kind of writing.) Curious.

111.speaker: Lae'zel
111.text: Tir'su markings. Ancient. I recognise them, but I can't make sense of... no, wait.
111.context: NodeContext: TEAR-soo. (A kind of writing.) Curious.

103.speaker: Lae'zel
103.text: The texts are enciphered, but I've solved the pattern. It's a story. About - about Orpheus.
103.context: NodeContext: Starts confident, then hesitates. This is is a heretical text.

167.speaker: Narrator
167.text: *Your head buzzes in concert with Lae'zel's, but it hardly matters. Even without the connection, you'd recognise her discomfort.*
167.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

135.speaker: Player
135.text: I've read this one already. What do you make of it?
135.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

16.speaker: Lae'zel
16.text: Drivel, all of it. Gith declared Vlaakith queen of the empire, and her own son defied her. Orpheus would have ceded control to the ghaik.

12.speaker: Player
12.text: And if it's true? It sounds like Vlaakith betrayed Gith and seized the throne.

60.speaker: Lae'zel
60.text: Well - enough conjecture. I'm done with the matter.

37.speaker: Player
37.text: The story reeks of propaganda, an attempt to foment discontent.

75.speaker: Player
75.text: Why are you so worked up? It's only a story.

108.speaker: Player
108.text: I've already deciphered the disc. What do you think?
108.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

158.speaker: Player
158.text: So you say. But what if the story is true, and this prince returns?

25.speaker: Player
25.text: 'Tir'su', you said. What does that mean?
25.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

120.speaker: Lae'zel
120.text: Githyanki writing. Every word a wheel, every letter a spoke.

164.speaker: Lae'zel
164.text: The most powerful texts are engraved in slate - some so ancient, only the most erudite gish can read them.

0.speaker: Player
0.text: Orpheus? Do you mean the famed prince?
0.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

44.speaker: Lae'zel
44.text: Yes. Famed - and long dead, the fool traitor.
44.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

168.speaker: Lae'zel
168.text: This text is heresy. I can hardly bear to read it, let alone speak it.
168.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

106.speaker: Player
106.text: You'll bear it just fine. Tell me what it says.
106.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

136.speaker: Lae'zel
136.text: Very well. I will read it to you.
136.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

58.speaker: Lae'zel
58.text: 'The Prince of the Comet, Part One.'
58.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

9.speaker: Lae'zel
9.text: 'So it was that we were free from ghaik shackles and turned our blades on each other. The heavens were shattered, and one great empire was divided in two.'
9.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

183.speaker: Lae'zel
183.text: 'Gith travelled to the Hells to broker help for her people, her cause. Vlaakith would have you believe Mother Gith proclaimed her our queen.'
183.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

49.speaker: Lae'zel
49.text: 'Lies! Gith made no such proclamation. Vlaakith seized the empire against the Mother's wishes.'
49.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

193.speaker: Lae'zel
193.text: 'But Gith had nurtured a son. Orpheus, Prince of the Comet, the True Heir! He knew Vlaakith's treachery.'
193.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

104.speaker: Lae'zel
104.text: 'Orpheus rallied Gith's honour guard and declared the throne for himself. The War of the Comet had begun.'
104.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

31.speaker: Lae'zel
31.text: The slate holds the truth. The prince still comes for his throne.
31.context: NodeContext: Can be said whether Lae'zel is sided with Orpheus or Vlaakith, so take care not to be too emotional either way.

131.speaker: Lae'zel
131.text: Truth or not, it matters no longer. Orpheus is fallen. Vlaakith reigns supreme.
131.context: NodeContext: Can be said whether Lae'zel is sided with Orpheus or Vlaakith, so take care not to be too emotional either way.

69.speaker: Lae'zel
69.text: Incredible tale. I wouldn't have believed it, if we hadn't seen the prince for ourselves.
69.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel now commenting harshly on what she just read

144.speaker: Lae'zel
144.text: A profane tale. These lies must perish with the prince who told them.
144.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel now commenting harshly on what she just read

30.speaker: Lae'zel
30.text: Disregard this - this drivel. Gith declared Vlaakith queen of the empire, and her own son defied her. Orpheus would have ceded control to the ghaik.
30.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel now commenting harshly on what she just read

91.speaker: Player
91.text: And if it's true? It sounds like Vlaakith betrayed Gith and seized the throne.
91.context: NodeContext: KITH-rack. Calming down and considering that maybe what you suggested wasn't so unthinkable.

143.speaker: Lae'zel
143.text: Chk. You speak like Kith'rak Voss. You accuse Vlaakith of the unthinkable.
143.context: NodeContext: KITH-rack. Calming down and considering that maybe what you suggested wasn't so unthinkable.

32.speaker: Lae'zel
32.text: As unthinkable as the greatest living knight turning on his queen...
32.context: NodeContext: KITH-rack. Calming down and considering that maybe what you suggested wasn't so unthinkable.

115.speaker: Lae'zel
115.text: Well - enough conjecture. I did what you asked, so let's be done with it.

107.speaker: Lae'zel
107.text: She did nothing of the sort.

1.speaker: Lae'zel
1.text: Thank your good fortunes I'm a tolerant woman, or I'd have sliced off a few toes for suggesting it.

39.speaker: Player
39.text: The story reeks of propaganda, an attempt to foment discontent.

82.speaker: Lae'zel
82.text: And so it is. A fabrication.

170.speaker: Lae'zel
170.text: A clever one, too, to masquerade as an ancient history. How many such stories could there be. And how many minds have been warped by them?

17.speaker: Player
17.text: Why are you so worked up? It's only a story.

130.speaker: Lae'zel
130.text: A ludicrous one, at that. Vlaakith seized the empire from my peoples' very mother?

165.speaker: Lae'zel
165.text: The queen would take that foolish child's head for so much as whispering this rubbish, were it to reach her ears.

23.speaker: Lae'zel
23.text: The queen would take even a child's head for so much as whispering this rubbish.

45.speaker: Narrator
45.text: *Your tadpoles connect, and you see the truth: Lae'zel speaks with conviction, but she's riddled with doubt.*

100.speaker: Lae'zel
100.text: 'The Prince of the Comet, Part Two.'
100.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

175.speaker: Lae'zel
175.text: 'The Prince of the Comet, Orpheus himself, led his honour guard into battle. Their red dragons bellowed with righteous anger, and the heavens erupted.'
175.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

178.speaker: Lae'zel
178.text: 'The glorious prince cried to all who could hear him: Praise be to my mother Gith, the Queen of the One Sky, sacrificed to the Hells by the renegade Vlaakith!'
178.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

88.speaker: Lae'zel
88.text: 'But the True Heir, the Prince of the Comet, could not overcome Vlaakith's knights and their ill-gotten wyrms. Mighty Voss, Jhe'stil Kith'rak, lit the astral sky aflame.'
88.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly. zhe-STIL KITH-rack

5.speaker: Lae'zel
5.text: 'When the ash had cleared, beloved Orpheus was gone.'
5.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel reading from a book, matter of factly

123.speaker: Lae'zel
123.text: So says the text. Orpheus was gone, yes. But most certainly not dead.
123.context: NodeContext: Can be said whether Lae'zel is sided with Orpheus or Vlaakith, so take care not to be too emotional either way.

121.speaker: Lae'zel
121.text: So says the text. Orpheus was gone, yes. But of course, he wasn't dead - not yet.
121.context: NodeContext: Can be said whether Lae'zel is sided with Orpheus or Vlaakith, so take care not to be too emotional either way.

190.speaker: Lae'zel
190.text: Incredible tale. I wouldn't have believed it, if we hadn't seen the prince for ourselves.
190.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel now commenting harshly on what she just read

138.speaker: Lae'zel
138.text: A profane tale. These lies must perish with the prince who told them.
138.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel now commenting harshly on what she just read

42.speaker: Lae'zel
42.text: 'True Heir'. 'Glorious Prince'. Chk. There's no greater crime than to exalt the pretender called Orpheus.
42.context: NodeContext: Lae'zel now commenting harshly on what she just read

191.speaker: Lae'zel
191.text: Disregard this - this drivel. Gith declared that Vlaakith should be queen. Orpheus would have ceded control to the ghaik.

173.speaker: Lae'zel
173.text: 'The Prince of the Comet, Part Three.'
173.context: NodeContext: Reading a story, matter of factly. zhe-STILL KITH-rack. eff-ELL-eh-mahn

128.speaker: Lae'zel
128.text: 'The histories tell us that Commander Voss, Jhe'stil Kith'rak, pierced Prince Orpheus clean through with his sword of silver. That his flesh was torn and fed to the great red dragon Ephelomon.'
128.context: NodeContext: Reading a story, matter of factly. zhe-STILL KITH-rack. eff-ELL-eh-mahn

155.speaker: Lae'zel
155.text: 'Vlaakith's faithful roar out this tale. But beneath the roars, we hear whispers carrying truth and prophecy.'
155.context: NodeContext: Can be said whether Lae'zel is sided with Orpheus or Vlaakith, so take care not to be too emotional either way.

146.speaker: Lae'zel
146.text:
'The Prince of the Comet is not dead.
The Prince of the Comet will come again.
The Prince of the Comet will liberate us from Vlaakith's tyranny.'
146.context: NodeContext: Can be said whether Lae'zel is sided with Orpheus or Vlaakith, so take care not to be too emotional either way.

90.speaker: Lae'zel
90.text: 'Praise be to Mother Gith, Queen of the One Sky! Praise be to your son Orpheus, the True Heir, Prince of the Comet!'
90.context: NodeContext: Can be said whether Lae'zel is sided with Orpheus or Vlaakith, so take care not to be too emotional either way.

7.speaker: Lae'zel
7.text: The story is true - Orpheus is free. And right here, right now, we are writing its next chapter.
7.context: NodeContext: Can be said whether Lae'zel is sided with Orpheus or Vlaakith, so take care not to be too emotional either way.

186.speaker: Lae'zel
186.text: We know how this story truly ends. With the death of the prince, and a throne left unchallenged.
186.context: NodeContext: Can be said whether Lae'zel is sided with Orpheus or Vlaakith, so take care not to be too emotional either way.

141.speaker: Lae'zel
141.text: Vlaakith has reigned unchallenged for millennia. Freeing Orpheus could be the first strike in a new war - as well as its last.

189.speaker: Lae'zel
189.text: Tsk'va. A failed prophecy. The Prince of the Comet will not live long enough to seize Vlaakith's throne.

132.speaker: Lae'zel
132.text: This is more than a fable - it's an affront to the Undying Queen Vlaakith. Gith's son died to Voss' blade. Orpheus is no more.

76.speaker: Player
76.text: So you say. But what if the story is true, and this prince returns?

61.speaker: Lae'zel
61.text: Chk. You speak like Kith'rak Voss. You accuse Vlaakith of the unthinkable.

142.speaker: Player
142.text: Why are you so worked up? It's only a story.

55.speaker: Lae'zel
55.text: A dangerous one. Lies have a way of spreading, until they cannot be discerned from the truth.

156.speaker: Player
156.text: Could Orpheus really be alive, do you think?

87.speaker: Lae'zel
87.text: It is not just improbable - it is impossible.

68.speaker: Lae'zel
68.text: Kith'rak Voss and his red dragon slayed the fell prince. You could no more resurrect him than you could glue together the pile of ashes he became.

10.speaker: Lae'zel
10.text: Traitor he may be, but even I wouldn't doubt Voss' greatest triumph.

118.speaker: Lae'zel
118.text: My varsh taught that the silver bells of Vlaakith's court still ring out before every hunt in celebration of the prince's defeat.

140.speaker: Lae'zel
140.text: As a child, I longed to hear them for myself, and sing in praises to the deathless queen and her kith'raki.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: Who is the great red dragon Ephelomon of the story?

95.speaker: Lae'zel
95.text: Tiamat's emissary. It was he who carried word that Mother Gith had negotiated the gift of the dragons -

79.speaker: Lae'zel
79.text: - and that Vlaakith the First would preside as queen of the githyanki.

105.speaker: Lae'zel
105.text: Ephelomon remains the queen's consort to this day, as endless as the empire he now serves.

96.speaker: Player
96.text: That's fine. I'll read it on my own time.

157.speaker: Lae'zel
157.text: If you must. Nothing good can come of it.

102.speaker: Player
102.text: I understand. Keep it to yourself.

151.speaker: Player
151.text: Go on already. What's it say?

161.speaker: Player
161.text: You look uneasy. Are you all right?

97.speaker: Lae'zel
97.text: I am fine. The slate is not.

13.speaker: Lae'zel
13.text: Listen close. I'll read it to you.

48.speaker: Lae'zel
48.text: Hm. Quite similar to the boy's slate from the crèche.

145.speaker: Lae'zel
145.text: It's a story. About - about Orpheus.

134.speaker: Lae'zel
134.text: The tir'su are enciphered, but I see the pattern. It's another story about Orpheus.

57.speaker: Player
57.text: I don't need to hear it.

150.speaker: Lae'zel
150.text: Better to leave it, I agree.

126.speaker: Lae'zel
126.text: Listen. I'll read you the text.

71.speaker: Player
71.text: *Once again, your mind opens to Lae'zel, and she considers the disc.*

166.speaker: Narrator
166.text: *Once again, your mind opens to Lae'zel, and she considers the disc.*

109.speaker: Lae'zel
109.text: More writings on Orpheus, the so-called Prince of the Comet.

67.speaker: Player
67.text: Go on, then. Let's hear it.

73.speaker: Player
73.text: I understand if you want to keep it to yourself.

113.speaker: Lae'zel
113.text: Good. Let that be the end of it.

70.speaker: Lae'zel
70.text: More writings on Orpheus, the Prince of the Comet.
